node.text:
Learn more @sakijapaneselessons 

Vocabulary 
ポテト
poteto
(French fries)
チーズバーガー
(cheeseburger)
〜ください。
〜kudasai
(Can I get 〜？/I’d like〜)
お願いします。
おねがいします。
onegaishimasu
(Please)
持ち帰り
もちかえり
mochikaeri
(to go)
コーラ
kora
(Coke)

The first part is subtitled. Also I spoke slowly. The second part isn’t subtitles and I spoke with a normal speed.
Please practice with the first part, and then try to do the second part!
Then you will be ready to order at Macdonald’s in Japanese :)

If you like this video, please don’t forget to like, save and share with your friends :)

#nihongo #japanese #jlpt #japaneseteacher #learnjapanese #japan #lovejapan #macdonalds #🇯🇵 #🇯🇵japan #katakana #hiragana #kanji #romaji #onlinejaoaneselessons #onlinejaoaneselesson #japanesetutor #privatejaoaneselesson #日本語 #にほんご #nihon #にほん

node.title: How to order at Macdonald’s in Japanese

node.text:
Learn more @sakijapaneselessons 
Sometimes one small mistake can make a big difference!
But please don’t be afraid of speaking Japanese!
Have you ever experienced pronouncing any words differently and caused a miscommunication? If so, please share the words with us!

I’d really appreciate it if you like this kind of video!

#nihongo #japaneselesson #日本語 #にほんご #learnjapanese #japaneseteacher #japanesetutor #japan #🇯🇵 #👘 #日本 #studyjapanese #japanlover #nippon #tochigi #learningjapanese

node.title: One small mistake can make a big difference

node.text:
Learn more @sakijapaneselessons 

Vocabulary 
事務所(じむしょ/jimusho)...office
引き出し(ひきだし/hikidashi)...drawer
中(なか/naka)...inside, in
猫(ねこ/neko)...cat
ポスト(posuto)...mailbox
コンビニ(konbini)...convenience store
犬(いぬ/inu)...dog
あそこ(asoko)...over there
男の人(おとこのひと/otokonohito)...man

Did you understand the difference between “imasu” and “arimasu”?
If it is still not really clear, please do not hesitate to leave your comments!

If you understood the sentence structure, please try question No.1 and 2 and leave the answers in the comments :)

If you like this video, please like, save and share this with yo ur friends!
Thank you so much for your support!

#nihongo #imasu #arimasu #日本語 #japaneselesson #learnjapanese #nihon #nippon #にほんご #kanji #hiragana #katakana #日本語の先生 #japaneseteacher #tipsforlearningjapanese #jlpt #jlptn5 #jlptn4 #sakijapaneselesson #sakijapaneselessons #japan #tochigi

node.text:
Please follow @sakijapaneselessons 
Let’s learn how to conjugate Te-form!
masu form→Te form
Learning sentence patterns with the-form can expand your Japanese speaking ability!
I know it would be first at first. But you will definitely get used to using them!

Singer : Maya
Studied piano and vocal in New York. She is currently working as singer and also as a singing teacher based in Tokyo. She has won a first prize for world famous entertainment show, the Amateur night at the Apollo theater. Her voice is pure and clean but very powerful and energetic. You won’t believe how her strong voice comes out from her tiny body! 

Weibo 
https://weibo.com/u/7361818556

YouTube
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaj8q0-votw7AEiLe8OaMOw

iTunes 
https://music.apple.com/jp/album/ucyuu-talk-single/1488295241?l=en

Track making : Kenta Ishihara (Yoara Research Laboratory )
Creator/Jazz pianist
He is an artist based in Tokyo. He devotes his unique philosophy to his works. The works is on YouTube channel “Yoara Research Laboratory” where you can see the world you have never seen. 

YouTube 
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC9E5WEoxOflQc9lYGW6GWqA

node.text:
Please follow @sakijapaneselessons 
I tried to use literal translations as much as possible. But the letters are too small to see, and that’s why I couldn’t write two translations. 
You might be feel weird with some of translations. 

Most of my students will graduate from my Japanese language schools next month.
I’ll miss them so much.
I’m not sure if I’ll be missed, though. Lol
I picked up some of our conversations and made this video, and I realized we have a lot of memories. 
It hasn’t really hit me they will leave my schools soon. But I’m sure I’ll miss them so much.....

Does anyone go to Japanese language school here? If so, will you graduate next month?
Im sure that your teacher will definitely miss you!!

It you have any requests about my insta posts, please feel free to let me know in the comments :)

Please don’t forget to save this amazing post!!

node.text:
Please follow @sakijapaneselessons 
Have you ever join a goukon party? 
It’s very popular here.
People love to ask the question “How old do you think I look like?” even though people obviously answer an age that is younger than how we look.
Also this answer only makes ONE PERSON feel happy and doesn’t produce anything else.
Also lots of Japanese people don’t really answer questions right away. 
Somehow we put on airs even if the answers are bullshit. I know it’s annoying.  But we love to start guessing games.

Lots of us don’t really answer our occupation especially people who often join Goukon.
I personally don’t really like to join Goukon since pretty girls often asked me to join it and I had to serve as a foil to them with no pay. But pretty girls are usually good at making guys pay for the party, so I gorged myself to death.
Guys often asked me if I was unemployed. I don’t know why. 

It you have any requests about my insta posts, please feel free to let me know in the comments :)

Please don’t forget to save this amazing post!!

node.text:
Please follow @sakijapaneselessons 
ほんと(honto) is the shorten form of 本当(hontou) and we often use it in daily conversation.
But it sounds casual, and we never use it in the business email.

Do you often hear we saying “ne”?
I know lots of Japanese people add “ne” when they speak English, too!

I’d really appreciate it if you could leave 😍in the comments! 
Please do not forget to save this AMAZING post :)

node.text:
Please follow @sakijapaneselessons 
Hello everyone!
Today I really would like to thank all your support in 2020.
It will be the last post of 2020!!
With your help, I was able to continue to teach Japanese here and I hope you enjoyed my lessons this year.
ありがとうございました！
arigatou gozaimashita!!
Thank you very much!!
よいお年を！
よいおとしを！
I wish you a very happy new year!!
.
.
.

node.text:
Please follow @sakijapaneselessons Japanese is considered as a high-context culture. It means that the rules of communication are primarily transmitted through the use of contextual elements such as a person's status and tone of voice, and they are not explicitly stated. I was born and raised in Japan, but somehow I’m terrible at understanding the high context culture. Today I picked up some phrases that Japanese people often say and I want you to find out what this senpai really means with me.
If you like this post, please don’t forget to like this video! Also please share this video with your friends and ask her opinions too!

node.text:
Learn more @sakijapaneselessons 

“itterasshai” might be too casual for your manager. (But it depends on the company.)
Sometimes we say “itterasshaimase” and this is a very polite version of “itterasshai”.
“Tadaima” is also too causal at the office sometimes. But it also depends on the company. Some people say “modorimashita(I returned)” instead. 
“Okaeri” is definitely too casual at the office. (If your co-worker is close to you, you might say this only to him or her.)
We say “okaerinasai”
It’s the polite form. But it isn’t too polite to use at the home as well. Some wives and kids say “okaerinasai” when their husband or dad came back home. But I don’t really hear husbands or dads say this. 

#nihongo #japaneselesson #日本語
#にほんご #japaneseteacher

node.text:
Follow me ⏩ @sakijapaneselessons 

I am often asked this question. 
Both of them can be used to determine a direction or a location. That’s why sometimes they are interchangeable. However, ni indicates more about the destination while e is more about the path to the destination. 
We do not say 電車へ乗る(でんしゃへのる/densha e noru) We say 電車に乗る(でんしゃにのる/densha ni noru)

Thank you so much for watching this video :)

node.text:
Follow @sakijapaneselessons 

Collaboration with one of my students @tre.v20!!

We you invite someone to do something, you can use the following sentence pattern.

masu form +masenka 

一緒にごはん食べませんか。
いっしょにごはんたべませんか。
isshoni gohan tabemasenka

You can add the particle “o” after gohan. But we often omit the particle “o” in this case.

This is a polite form. 
The plain form is

一緒にごはん食べない?
いっしょにごはんたべない？
isshoni gohan tabenai?

If you like this video, please share this with your friends!
Thank you so much for yo support :)!

node.text:
Follow @sakijapaneselessons 

“Masenka” is a negative of “masu”
But it’s also used to invite someone to do something.
“Isshoni” means “together”

Have you ever felt textbook Japanese and real Japanese conversation are different? If so, in what situation did you feel that?
I’d really appreciate it if you could share it with us!

Thank you so much for your support :)!!

node.text:
Learn more @sakijapaneselessons 

Do you watch the Olympic Games?
Do you like sports?
Do you play any sports?
I used to play softball and I love it!
I wish I could join a softball team now, but it’s very hard to find it here!
It’s very popular for adult women to play volleyballs here! There are so many teams! They are usually called “ママさんバレー(mama san baree)”
but single women can join the teams too :)!!
What sport is popular in your countries?

node.text:
Follow @sakijapaneselessons 

You can use plain form for your family, Kouhai, friends or people who are close to you. Generally have to use polite from to elder people, Senpai, customers, people of higher status or people who you meet for the first time.

Thank you so much for your support!

node.text:
Follow @sakijapaneselessons 

This phrase would be very useful when you are learning Japanese.

____は日本語で何といいますか。
____はにほんごでなんといいますか。
____wa nihongo de nanto iimasuka
How do you say ___ in Japanese?

Anyway, can anyone answer the question in this video?

Thank you so much for your support!

Follow @sakijapaneselessons 

Sorry. I deleted the previous video sicne there was a typo! I’m reposting it! 
O’clock 
1👉いちじ(ichiji)
2👉にじ(niji)
3👉さんじ(sanji)
4👉よじ(yoji)
5👉ごじ(goji)
6👉ろくじ(rokuji)
7👉しちじ(shichiji)
8👉はちじ(hachiji)
9👉くじ(kuji)
10👉じゅうじ(juuji)
11👉じゅういちじ(juuichiji)
12👉じゅうにじ(juuniji)
We also use marine time in some certain situations. Usually stores and restaurants use marine time to show their open hours.
